0.author: haiskf
0.body:
“commonly called“ and “called“ are not the same thing. The former is subjective, whilst the latter is objective.  

You see, adding the qualifier “commonly“ implies that there are SOME people who use the term and some who don’t.  So, you are correct in that the statement “there is no country comedy called America“ would be false. There are some people who do refer to the United States as “America.”

That’s not the same as the statement “there is no country called America,” which is what I said.  So, if you’re going to be pedantic then you need to quote me correctly.  

The algebra analogy didn’t work, so I’m not going to address it.

0.author: Lord_Havelock
0.body:
It is called that. Called is not universal. If I decide to start saying England is actually Havelock Land, you would still say called England, despite the fact that it isn't universal. Conversely it would also be accurate to say that it was called Havelock Land. Because it is. It would be a very uncommon practice, probably just me, but it would still be a practice nonetheles.

The term *named* is perfectly objective, so long as world governments and such can agree. You can find the united states of America on a map, and they are named the united states of America.

Despite this, it is *called* many things. One of them is the United States of America. Another one is America. 

The Algebra analogy was specifically in regards to your claim that this is 'semantics' which, true to your word, you did not address at all.

0.author: haiskf
0.body: Enough with the analogies; they are not working for you.  The fact that you may call the United States “America,“ doesn’t mean that it is called America. The Ayatollah Khomeini used to call it “the great Satan.”That does not mean that the country is called the great Satan.

0.author: Lord_Havelock
0.body: I dunno, does anyone still call it that? If so "the great Satan" is indeed one of the things it is called. It is not its name, but it is called that.

0.author: haiskf
0.body: No it isn’t. With your liberal interpretation of the word, then literally anything could be called anything if some person calls it that.

0.author: Lord_Havelock
0.body: Yes! I'm glad you finally understand.

0.author: haiskf
0.body: Thanks for confirming that you have no actual point!

0.author: Lord_Havelock
0.body: That was my point. It was pedantic, unnecessary, and technical, but it has always been my point. You disagreed with me on that core fundamental, and we have been arguing about it. If I don't have a point, then what do you have? Because literally your entire stance is that I'm wrong.

0.author: haiskf
0.body: No, my entire stance is that there is no country called America. That hasn’t changed. This isn’t about you at all.

0.author: Lord_Havelock
0.body:
Right, because I said it was. Ergo, your stance was that I was wrong. Unless you are claiming either that

1. We can both be right and the US (sorry, i know that's not its name.) is both called, *and* not called, America. 

Or 2. Your comment was unrelated to me and what I said and no matter what my first comment had said, you intended to reply with the statement "There is no country called America." 

Which frankly, regardless of your feelings, I suspect you don't just randomly yell that at people with no context or reason.

0.author: haiskf
0.body: My stance is that there is no country called America.  But you can keep trying to make it about something else.

0.author: Lord_Havelock
0.body: I'm not trying to make it any something else? I'm confused, do I have no point, or do I have so many points it's making it hard for you to focus?

0.author: haiskf
0.body: If you’re confused, then maybe you should stop posting.

0.author: Lord_Havelock
0.body: Technically, I'm not posting. I'm commenting. It would be rather ridiculous if I made a new post each time you replied to me. It would kind of get out of hand.

1.author: Immediateload
1.body: I accept the scientific consensus that biologic sex is meaningful and that gender is irrelevant to the conversation.

1.author: Dow2Wod2
1.body:
But I did show how she lies about trans people, didn't I? She made a whole post about how letting them into women's spaces is dangerous.

I also showed you how she lied about transphobes, claiming they were targeted for unjustified reasons by HR.

What about this is far fetched? She really did just lie to attack trans people and to defend transphobes, this seems pretty conclusive to me.

1.author: Dow2Wod2
1.body:
There is no such consensus. "Women" means adult female human, and "female" denotes gender, not sex.

I never said biological sex wasn't meaningful, just that it doesn't determine womanhood specifically.

1.author: Immediateload
1.body: Lol bro female specifically denotes sex, not gender.  Clueless.

1.author: Dow2Wod2
1.body:
No it doesn't. The definition englobes things/people directly linked to sex as well as things merely related or associated with it.

Look up Forrest's video on the Matt Walsh debate to see for yourself, if you don't like my definition.

1.author: Immediateload
1.body:
Buddy, male and female are the words used to describe the sex of an animal.  
If I were to tell you a female chicken lays eggs do you think you need to take the chicken to a psychologist to figure out it’s gender?

1.author: Dow2Wod2
1.body:
Of course not, but you also miss that words can have complex and multiple definitions.

When talking of none human animals, female applies exclusively to the sex because they have no conception of gender, there is only one meaning the word can possibly take.

When talking about humans, you add the 'related' qualifier to include more possibilities.

This is not difficult to understand.

And just to reiterate, there is no scientific consensus over the things you talked about, because they are value judgements (meaning and relevance are not scientific concepts in the sense you use them).

2.author: Clean-Promotion-8250
2.body: Thats not how facts work and you don't know anyone else's "hits" as you put it. Good there's not a nihilistic world view. Now maybe work on removing that rather large chip that resides right there on your shoulder. More hits? The most you could find statistics on? Not here to argue or lessen your "hits". I actually do not happen to be an ahole. You sounds pretty proud of what you've been through and all too happy to compare yourself to everyone else, of whom you also know nothing. There are many different "hits" out there and underrreporting. Your lucky to be alive. What about your childhood friend? You're not just comparing yourself to the living when you try to stay on your deranged pedestal of suffering. I hope happy things can define and motivate you going forward rather than presuming your the tip hit getter.

2.author: BarkBeetleJuice
2.body:
>Thats not how facts work and you don't know anyone else's "hits" as you put it.

That **is** how statistics work. Most means more than half, and for the record *I never said I took more hits than most in my original post.* I said *I have overcome more than my fair share of obstacles.*

>Now maybe work on removing that rather large chip that resides right there on your shoulder.

I'm unsure why you think you're going to be helping me with *anything* when you don't understand what 1st grade words mean.

>I hope happy things can define and motivate you going forward rather than presuming your the tip hit getter.

Happy things **do** define me. My life experience was called into question and I responded with a small fraction of the hits I've taken. Do you think that post contained every obstacle I've ever overcome or every moment of joy I've had? lol. Fuck no. I also never said I was the "top hit getter," I replied to someone who cynically said "wait til life hits you."

Do us both a favor, piss off and learn to read.

2.author: Clean-Promotion-8250
2.body: Wow. You gas light yourself. You assume I don't know how to read? Work on your comprehension. Do you think others are posting about all their obstacles at jokes? I know how statistics work better than most. Unless, wait... God? Is that you? If you can't understand what is being said, stfu.

18.author: SheeBang_UniCron
18.body:
So you believe that there is a 50% chance the person you responded to was not lying?  

How about leprechauns? Do you believe in them?

18.author: Dragonatis
18.body:
Belief means assuming something is true without any proof.

Probabilistic logic is a proof I need, so I don't believe. I KNOW that other person MIGHT BE lying.

Whether it's 50% chance, 20% or 99.9999999% chance depends on a person and their knowledge in a topic. But you can never be 100% sure by testimony alone.

18.author: SheeBang_UniCron
18.body:
So you believe that you have interacted with someone who has a non-zero chance of having visited other planets?

What’s the probability that that person is also god? Aren’t you curious enough to find out for sure?

18.author: Dragonatis
18.body: There is also non-zero chance to win lottery. But that doesn't mean I should play as statistically, I need to spend much more money on tickets than I would win.

18.author: SheeBang_UniCron
18.body: Your example and my example are not even similar. People winning lotteries are easily provable. People visiting other planets (to use the example above) with the current technology and live to tell you about it is as likely as a god existing.

18.author: Dragonatis
18.body: Agree that winning lottery is much more probable than someone being god, but from statistical point of view, chance value is the only thing that is changing.

I have more years behind me than in front and am relatively unconcerned with my own demise. I've had a pretty good life so far and live a pretty good one now. There's not much to add, but whatever comes, comes.

So, that's how old I wanna get.

23.author: OriginalEmpress
23.body: Agreed! I grew up reading the original printing, so the movie confused me as a kid. I didn't realize until I researched it as an adult that they'd changed them twice, once into the hippies for the book, then into the orange guys for the movie.

23.author: BioletVeauregarde33
23.body: There are so many differences from the book to the movie that Roald Dahl openly hated the latter.

23.author: OriginalEmpress
23.body: I know,  and I hate that because Gene Wilder is such an incredible actor, I've always wondered if Roald hating the movie made him sad at all.

23.author: BioletVeauregarde33
23.body: One thing I know for sure is that Gene hated the (far more accurate) 2005 version. Which is a second adaptation of the book and not a "remake" as some people like to call it.

23.author: OriginalEmpress
23.body:
I'm with him there,  the second adaptation was closer to the book, but when it strayed, it strayed in WEIRD ways.

I call that one the Daddy Issues version.

24.author: Enderbraska_CZ

24.author: ArcTan_Pete
24.body:
*"Explaining a joke is like dissecting a frog. You understand it better, but the frog dies in the process"*

**"A little bird told me"** Is a common expression in the UK (and, I think, in Canada and the USA). It means that someone has told you something - usually something confidential/that you were not supposed to know - and you chose to keep their identity a secret.

Of course, if you **really** thought that a real 'little bird' was talking to you, and giving you confidential information, then it could be a sign that you were hallucinating

It is a pun - a play on words or phrases that have may have two, or more, different meaning.

as it is a pun, then - by definition - it is a joke.

If you dont like it, or - more likely - if you dont understand it, then you are free to pass it by without making a comment. 

I admit, I have done so with many jokes on this sub. But - something you may learn when you grow up - not everything in life, is made for **your** personal enjoyment

24.author: Enderbraska_CZ
24.body: Truly, if it's not a dark humor joke, it's okay someone finds it unfunny, but the classic joke should have a little bit of fun in it for everyone. In r/Jokes are many types of jokes that are so boring that even rats can make better jokes that that. And for that free to pass, we live in a democratic states where is freedom of speech, so if i want to share my opinion, i will do it.

24.author: ArcTan_Pete
24.body:
"We live in a democratic states where there is freedom of speech"

well, that may be true (for you) - and no one is going to drag you off to prison for giving your opinion - but freedom of speech doesn't mean you HAVE to give your opinion - as you will learn (hopefully) when you grow up.

and it doesn't mean freedom from consequences - such as me saying you are an immature moron who doesn't understand that other people may have a different idea of what is humorous and what is not
